description: Old French flagitieux or Latin flāgitiōsus, both ultimately from flāgitium (“shameful crime”), related to flagrum (“whip”).

adjectives.description: flagitious (comparative more flagitious, superlative most flagitious)

entries.meaning: (literary) Guilty of terrible crimes; wicked, criminal.
examples: This young Nobleman was not only a flagitious Punster himself, but was accessary to the Punning of others, by Consent, by Provocation, by Connivance, and by Defence of the Evil committed  […] .

entries.meaning: (literary) Extremely brutal or wicked; heinous, monstrous.
